Authors:
Ricarda Riina, Daniela S. Carneiro-Torres, Paul E. Berry,
Jess A. Peirson, Inês Cordeiro
Title:
Further support for the Crotoneae phylogeny: a new species of
Brasiliocroton based on morphological, geographical, and molecular
evidence
Keywords:
Bahia, Brasiliocroton muricatus, B. mamoninha, Brazil,
Crotoneae, Euphorbiaceae, nrITS, trnL-F
Abstract:
Brasiliocroton muricatus is a new species from eastern
Brazil that is described, illustrated, and placed in a phylogenetic
context. It is only the second known species of Brasiliocroton. Its
phylogenetic position was inferred based on sequences from the nrITS and
chloroplast trnL-F regions, using a sampling of closely related genera
in tribe Crotoneae. Brasiliocroton muricatus was recovered within tribe
Crotoneae forming a clade with B. mamoninha. This clade is in turn
sister to the large genus Croton, giving additional support to previous
phylogenetic studies including B. mamoninha. The most obvious
morphological characters distinguishing the new species from B.
mamoninha are the unisexual, axillary inflorescences and the smaller
fruits with muricate surface and white, stellate trichomes vs. bisexual,
terminal inflorescences and bigger fruits with smooth surface and
ochraceous to brown dendritic trichomes in B. mamoninha. Both species of
Brasiliocroton have the filaments of the staminate flowers erect in bud,
the main character distinguishing them from the closely related Croton
and Astraea.
